posts.title: The Schomburg Center Clipping Files
posts.text: One of the Schomburg's most popular resources is a collection that has been built personally by the hands of librarians for almost 100 years.

posts.title: NYPL’s Catherine Allen Latimer: The First Black Librarian at NYPL, Helped Create the Schomburg Center
posts.text: Beyond her work cultivating collections, Latimer showed that a librarian’s work could be far-reaching and not defined by one role.

posts.title: Researching Human Rights at The New York Public Library
posts.text: In honor of Universal Human Rights Month, The New York Public Library has created this list of online resources to help you explore all aspects of human rights—nationally and internationally.

posts.title: The Howard Colored Orphan Asylum: New York’s First Black-Run Orphanage
posts.text: The home got its start when Sarah Tillman began taking care of twenty Black children in her lower Manhattan home.

posts.title: Catherine Latimer: The New York Public Library's First Black Librarian
posts.text: The impact and body of work created by Latimer is significant and lives on today.

posts.title: San Juan Hill and the Black Nurses of the Stillman Settlement
posts.text: In the first post of a series exploring lesser-known areas of New York City that black people have lived in and impacted, we learn about black nurses who brought health care to the people of the San Juan Hill neighborhood.

posts.title: Moon Money: Apollo 11, Advertising, and the Media
posts.text: July 20, 2019 marks the 50th anniversary of the Apollo 11 moon landing.

posts.title: 'When They See Us': Researching the Story of the Exonerated 5 and Beyond at The New York Public Library
posts.text: This case is an integral part of New York City history and interest in it has rekindled. These NYPL resources can help you dig deeper into its details, background, and context.

posts.title: What Was John Wick Reading at The New York Public Library?
posts.text: Are you curious about that book that John Wick requests at The New York Public Library? Let our librarians tell you more about it.

posts.title: Before Online Dating: Vintage Love Advice with NYPL's E-Resources
posts.text: On this day of hearts, cards and candy, here are some tips we learned with e-resources to help those who might be looking for a significant other.

posts.title: Top Five Life Lessons From Newspapers.com
posts.text: Library staff and patrons of The New York Public Library have never been more excited about an online resource than they have been about Newspapers.com, and with very good reason!

posts.title: Finding Old Recipes with NYPL's Online Resources
posts.text: October is that time of of year where the days grow shorter, the weather turns colder, and we need some good comfort food. Often we think back to our favorite dishes we ate as children, which is perfect since October is also National Cookbook Month. Those favorite dishes may be difficult to find in individual cookbooks, but NYPL's e-resources are here to help.

posts.title: Researching the Salem Witch Trials and Other Firsthand Accounts
posts.text: The Salem Witch trials have become an integral part of American folklore—with plays, films, podcasts, and multiple books. For those who are interested in exploring this period of history further, take a look at The New York Public Library's online resources where patrons can read firsthand accounts of the witch trials of Salem Village and many others.

posts.title: Top 5 Online Learning Tools from NYPL
posts.text: Online learners can take part in courses on their own time, at their own pace, and at any location. That is why the New York Public Library provides access to a wide range of online learning tools.

posts.title: Behind the Dream: Researching Dr. King with Online Resources at NYPL
posts.text: In honor of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s "I Have a Dream" speech, The New York Public Library has put together this list of online resources that patrons can use to go behind the dream.

posts.title: Top 5 Online Resources to Help You Find That Book from NYPL
posts.text: NYPL provides access to many online resources available to patrons who are seeking something new to read, readalikes, or just looking for that book you vaguely remember but hope to find again.

posts.title: Flapper Fabulosity! Researching 1920s Fashion with Online Resources
posts.text: Each decade exhibits its own distinct style. The fashion of the "Roaring Twenties" is often associated with the "flapper"—loose fitting dresses, close cropped hair, and elaborate accessories. If you are interested in learning more about 1920s' fashion take advantage of some of the electronic resources available from the New York Public Library.

posts.title: Stonewall and Beyond: Researching LGBTQ History with NYPL's Online Resources
posts.text: If you are interested in researching LGBTQ history, The New York Public Library provides excellent electronic resources to expand your knowledge.

posts.title: On the Front Page: A Look Back at D-Day
posts.text: The small French region called Normandy was thrust into the history books on June 6, 1944 when it was chosen as the allied point of invasion to accelerate the end of the second World War. To understand the fervor surrounding this event take a look at some of the newspaper headlines of the day.

posts.title: Top Five Ways to Read and Watch Shakespeare Online with Your New York Public Library Card
posts.text: The New York Public Library provides more than 500 online research options, many accessible from home with a library card. We challenge you to go beyond the search engine and dig deeper online with NYPL.

posts.title: New York Public Library's Top 10 Best Kept Online Secrets
posts.text: NYPL provides access to over 500 electronic resources and we want to share some of our best kept secrets.

posts.title: Celebrating World Theatre Day with NYPL E-Resources
posts.text: Here is a quick list of online resources provided by the New York Public Library for theatre lovers old and new!

posts.title: Women's History Month: Researching with NYPL's E-Resources
posts.text: Explore unique and lesser-known online resources containing materials about women's history.

posts.title: W.E.B. Du Bois Vacationed in Jamaica and Other Discoveries from NYPL's E-Resources
posts.text: On February 23, 1868, the famed African American sociologist, scholar, historian, journalist, and activist was born. To learn more about Mr. Du Bois, we dug into The New York Public Library's electronic resources to see what we could find.

posts.title: Researching Black Heritage with NYPL's E-Resources
posts.text: The New York Public Library has created this list of online resources to help you explore all aspects of Black heritage—from genealogy to LGBT history to current popular culture.

posts.title: It's International Creativity Month and You Haven't Met Lynda?
posts.text: If you're searching for ways to expand your creativity, then it's time you met Lynda! The New York Public Library provides free access from any location to Lynda.com with a valid NYPL card and pin number.

posts.title: On the Front Page: A Look Back at Pearl Harbor
posts.text: Take a look at front pages covering the attack on Pearl Harbor from across the United States and from around the world.

posts.title: Native American Indian & Alaska Native Heritage Month: Researching with E-Resources
posts.text: In celebration of Native American Indian and Alaska Native Heritage Month, The New York Public Library has created this quick list of online resources to help get you started as you explore all aspects of Native American and Alaska Native heritage.

posts.title: Everything You Need to Write and Publish Your Book using NYPL's E-Resources
posts.text: The New York Public Library prides itself on supporting writers of every kind.  It doesn't matter if you are writing a comic book, a biography, or the next great American novel, we have the tools to help you succeed. In addition to thousands of print resources, NYPL also offers a large number of electronic resources to help you research, write and publish your work.

posts.title: Hispanic Heritage Month: A Guide to NYPL's E-Resources
posts.text: In celebration of Hispanic Heritage Month, The New York Public Library has created this list of online resources to help you explore all aspects of Hispanic heritage—from genealogy to LGBTQ history to current popular culture.

posts.title: Free Online Magazines & Newspapers from The New York Public Library
posts.text: With a library card, NYPL offers you hundreds of magazines and newspapers online for free! See what's popular.

posts.title: Vice Wars: Researching New York City's Scandalous Censorship Past
posts.text: On April 29, 1947 a man entered the office of the Random House publishing company in mid-town Manhattan. He told the receptionist that he would like to purchase a book of poetry. The following day, a small raiding party of police detectives entered the Random House office, thrusting a summons and a search warrant in the receptionist's face...

posts.title: Jesse Owens & Athletes Who Protest (or Don't)
posts.text: He solidified his name as one of the most important athletic figures in history—not only for his record breaking speed, but for where and when he won his Olympic medals. However, an incredibly similar situation threw him into the midst of controversy thirty-two years later.

posts.title: Fake News Isn't New: Researching Its History with NYPL's E-Resources
posts.text: The term "fake news" may be receiving a lot of attention lately, but it is by no means new or unique to this day and age.

posts.title: Exploring the History of the Swimsuit with NYPL's Electronic Resources
posts.text: How did the swimsuit, as we know it today, come about? The New York Public Library has a number of great electronic resources for anyone interested in current and historical fashions.

posts.title: The Alternative Press: A Look Back at Transvestia
posts.text: Small and independent publications—including, journals, pamphlets, magazines, newspapers, and more recently zines, social media, and independent online news magazines—are priceless when understanding the history of these groups, movements, and communities.

posts.title: Researching Juneteenth Celebrations at The New York Public Library
posts.text: Juneteenth is a holiday celebrated across the country commemorating the formal emancipation of slaves in the United States.

posts.title: Pencils At Dawn! 6 Writers and the Duels They Fought In
posts.text: We did some digging into our collections and stories of writers who fought in, died in, or narrowly avoided duels. Here are six fascinating tales of literary “affairs of honor:”

posts.title: Arthur Conan Doyle: Researching Crimes and Detectives with NYPL's E-Resources
posts.text: By exploring The New York Public Library's Crime, Punishment, and Popular Culture database—a digital archive that presents a broad history of crime in the 19th century with over 2 million pages of primary source materials, including manuscripts, books, broadsheets, and periodicals—we can begin to understand what might have inspired the most iconic detective books of all time.

posts.title: Explore Historic Women Journalists with NYPL's Electronic Resources
posts.text: In honor of Helen Bernstein and the 30th anniversary of the Helen Bernstein Book Award for Excellence in Journalism, take a look at some of the work by famous women journalists from our databases.

posts.title: Discovering the Forgotten History of Mother's Day with NYPL's Electronic Resources
posts.text: Sunday is Mother's Day—a day of flowers, cards and brunches. How did this special day to celebrate all mothers actually begin?

posts.title: Celebrating Law Day: The 14th Amendment & NYPL's Electronic Resources
posts.text: This week, The New York Public Library is celebrating Law Day by focusing on arguably the most impactful amendment to the United States Constitution—the 14th Amendment.
